conclusion: To solve for the magnitude of the normal force F_N between the locking tongue D and the locking groove E when the door is in the self-locking state, we need to analyze the forces acting on the latch D.
The forces acting on the latch D can be categorized into: Spring Force, Frictional Force, and Normal Force.
Spring Force: The spring C exerts a force F_s = kx (where x is the compression distance of the spring).
Frictional Force: The frictional force F_f acts along the inclined surface of the latch D.
Normal Force: The normal force F_N acts perpendicular to the inclined surface of the latch D.
Resolve the forces into components parallel and perpendicular to the inclined plane.
The component of the spring force parallel to the inclined plane is F_{s\parallel} = F_s \cos(\theta) = kx \cos(30^\circ) = kx \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}
The component of the frictional force parallel to the inclined plane is F_{f\parallel} = \mu F_N \cos(\theta) = \mu F_N \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}

premise: Self-locking state implies net force parallel to the inclined plane must be zero.
